resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
bkmgit opened a new pull request, #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430

   This ensures commits are not lost unintentionally, see  
   https://itnext.io/git-force-vs-force-with-lease-9d0e753e8c41

kou commented on code in PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#discussion_r996494256


##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,19 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use `--force-with-lease`

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
       should use ``--force-with-lease``
   ```



##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,19 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use `--force-with-lease`
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
+
+    If that fails, use a regular `--force` push.

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
       If that fails, use a regular ``--force`` push.
   ```
   
   BTW, should we try `pull` and `push --force-with-lease` before we use `--force`?

bkmgit commented on code in PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#discussion_r996601627


##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,19 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use `--force-with-lease`
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
+
+    If that fails, use a regular `--force` push.

Review Comment:
   Usually have needed to do this after rebasing. If this is done frequently, maybe better to change the git config settings to make it the default.

pitrou commented on code in PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#discussion_r996901762


##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,19 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use ``--force-with-lease``
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
+
+    If that fails, use a regular ``--force`` push.

Review Comment:
   Instead of stating the `--force` alternative, I think it would be better to explain in one simple sentence why `--force-with-lease` is preferrable over `--force` (because that option is not very well-known).

pitrou commented on PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#issuecomment-1280656641

   Thanks @bkmgit, I think few of us knew about this safer alternative.

bkmgit commented on code in PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#discussion_r997172220


##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,19 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use ``--force-with-lease``
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
+
+    If that fails, use a regular ``--force`` push.

Review Comment:
   Thanks for the feedback. Needed two sentences. Hopefully ok. Not sure if a link to the [documentation](https://git-scm.com/docs/git-push) is needed.

pitrou commented on code in PR #14430:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14430#discussion_r997191624


##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,18 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use ``--force-with-lease``

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
       should use ``--force-with-lease``:
   ```



##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,18 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use ``--force-with-lease``
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
 
+    The option ``force-with-lease`` will fail if the remote has commits that are not available
+    locally, for example if additional commits have been made by a colleague.  By using
+    ``force-with-lease`` instead of ``force``, you ensure those commits are not overwritten

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
       ``--force-with-lease`` instead of ``--force``, you ensure those commits are not overwritten
   ```



##########
docs/source/developers/overview.rst:
##########
@@ -64,12 +64,18 @@ checklist for using ``git``:
     straightforward.
 
     Once you have an updated local copy, you can push to your remote repo.  Note, since your
-    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.
+    remote repo still holds the old history, you would need to do a force push.  Most pushes
+    should use ``--force-with-lease``
 
     .. code:: console
 
-       $ git push --force origin branch
+       $ git push --force-with-lease origin branch
 
+    The option ``force-with-lease`` will fail if the remote has commits that are not available

Review Comment:
   ```suggestion
       The option ``--force-with-lease`` will fail if the remote has commits that are not available
   ```

fields.summary: Suggest use force with lease where possible
